ygData.subject: Re: How can geometric relationship be exploited in virtual creature controllers?
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, thanks for pointing out Tyler s recent work.  I had not been aware of it.  It does indeed look like an approach that could work well with HyperNEAT,

Peter, thanks for pointing out Tyler's recent work.  I had not been
aware o=
f it.  It does indeed look like an approach that could work
well with Hyper=
NEAT, perhaps automating the configuration of substrate
input layers.  It's=
 a nice idea.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "peterberrington" <peterbe=
rrington@...>
wrote:
>
> Thanks for the informative response Ken. Actually,=
 someone sent me a
> link to this website earlier and I found it surprising=
ly relevant:
> http://www.vrac.iastate.edu/~streeter/
> It's Tyler Streeter=
's page, I believe he posts here as well.
> 
> On the projects page, there =
is a picture of a blue face which leads to
> the Somatopic Map project page=
. It looks like there is actually a lot
> of exploiting geometry going on i=
n our own motor systems and the
> method Tyler has devised for unwrapping a=
 3d model into a 2d map while
> preserving its topology sounds like it woul=
d make the perfect
> candidate for hyperneat. Although it might not be appl=
icable for
> joints with >1 degrees of freedom, my current ragdoll rig skir=
ts that
> issue by only using hinge joints, places at opposing angles/offse=
ts in
> order to emulate the ball-socket joints we have in our arms/legs. 
=
> It would obviously make more sense if there was a touch sensor like
> ski=
n on this model and that was incorporated into the dynamics, but it
> still=
 sounds like it could work if you just mark the physical
> locations of inp=
uts on the unwrapped map.
> Perhaps you could unwrap a virtual creature of =
any shape using that
> method, and mark the location of inputs which have a=
 physical location
> on the surface of the creature. That would allow a ver=
y flexible way
> of approaching this task for almost any creature morpholog=
y
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:=

> >
> > Peter, how to represent the geometry of a rag doll in the substrat=
e is
> > an open question right now with a lot of possible answers.  The
> =
> easiest part of the answer is probably just that the inputs and
> > outpu=
ts should be in a configuration that is projected from the shape
> > of the=
 body, and both inputs and outputs should have correlated
> geometry.
> > 
=
> > However, the little questions are the hard ones, like what to do when
>=
 > there are multiple degrees of freedom at the same location (such as a
> =
> hip).  It seems erroneous to simply squeeze such different directions
> >=
 arbitrarily into the same area. Perhaps more useful would be to have
> > m=
ultiple input and output layers, each with a map of the joints of the
> > b=
ody that rotate along a certain axis.
> > 
> > The multiple layers could be=
 joined together on a 3rd dimension, or
> > effectively completely separate=
d by making them separate inputs or
> > outputs (i.e. by having multiple se=
ts of inputs or outputs).  
> > 
> > To simplify the problem, you might sta=
rt out for practice with a robot
> > that only has a single degree of freed=
om at each joint.  That way, you
> > could just have a single input map and=
 a single output map without any
> > difficult conceptual issues.  If it wo=
rks out well, you could expand
> > from there to more complex representatio=
ns.
> > 
> > Like I said, this research area is an experiment in progress, =
but I do
> > believe we will eventually have some standard practices for ho=
w to
> > project a body onto a substrate.  I'd be interested in hearing
> >=
 anything you find out.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"peterberrington" <peterberrington@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > In other words,=
 how do you configure a substrate for hyperneat for a
> > > list of inputs =
that correspond to joint angles and velocities and a
> > > list of outputs =
that correspond to the desired joint state (i.e.
hold,
> > > relax, extend,=
 or contract)?
> > > 
> > > Vinod K. Valsalam wrote an excellent paper on m=
aking modular
> > > subnetworks in order to take advantage of a symmetrical=

configuration
> > > of legs, as in a quadruped trot, bound, pace or "pronk=
". This sounds
> > > like a good idea, but in the case of a biped or humano=
id
creature (for
> > > example, the ragdoll rig I'm currently working on ha=
s 20 1-dof
> > > joints), I'm not sure I want to limit myself from explorin=
g behavior
> > > that isn't strictly modular with respect to the limb. Symm=
etry
is only
> > > bilateral in a humanoid, you won't achieve as dramatic a=

reduction in
> > > search space as you do with 4 or more symmetrical limbs=
 by
> > > compartmentalizing it that way.
> > > 
> > > So the question is, =
how do I lay out my ragdoll model in the
substrate
> > > if I want to take =
advantage of the geometric relationship
between the
> > > joints in the bod=
y?
> > >
> >
>
